title: 103_hr3300
content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act of 1960, which promotes wildlife conservation on military reservations. SEC. 3. INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR MILITARY INSTALLATIONS. Section 101(a) (16 U.S.C. 670a(a)) is amended to require the Secretary to prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for each military installation in the United States. The Secretary must prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with an exception if deemed inappropriate by the Secretary. Amendments include changes to section 101(b) regarding cooperative plans. The Secretary determines that preparing a plan for the installation is not appropriate. Conforming amendments include changing "cooperative plan" to "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections. The Secretary determines that preparing a plan for the installation is not appropriate. Conforming amendments include changing "cooperative plan" to "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections. The Secretary decides against creating a plan for the installation and makes changes to replace "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan" in different sections. The Secretary decides against creating a plan for the installation and replaces "cooperative plan" with "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections. The Secretary replaces "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" in various sections of the resource management plan. Amendments are made to the contents of the plans in section 101(b). Amendments are made to the contents of resource management plans, including wetland protection and restoration, wetland creation, and consideration of conservation needs for all biological communities. Amendments are made to resource management plans by adding wetland protection and restoration, wetland creation, consideration of conservation needs for all biological communities, and establishing specific natural resource management goals and objectives. Amendments to resource management plans include addressing needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation for military installations. The resource management plan for military installations must address needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation. It should ensure integration and consistency among activities, no net loss in land capability for the military mission, and sustained public use of natural resources. The resource management plan for military installations aims to ensure no net loss in land capability for the military mission and provide sustained public access to natural resources. The resource management plan for military installations aims to ensure no net loss in land capability for the military mission and provide sustained public access to natural resources, including professional enforcement of natural resource laws and regulations. The Secretary of Defense shall provide an opportunity for public comment on each integrated natural resource plan, ensuring professional enforcement of natural resource laws and regulations. The Secretary of Defense shall allow public comment on integrated natural resource management plans. SEC. 4. REVIEW OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS FOR INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States under their jurisdiction to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. This report must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within 9 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Defense must review military installations to determine the need for integrated natural resource management plans. A report on these determinations must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Defense must review military installations for integrated natural resource management plans and submit a report to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment, listing installations where such plans are not deemed necessary, along with explanations for each. The Secretary of Defense must provide explanations for military installations where integrated natural resource management plans are deemed unnecessary within 2 years of the initial report to Congress. The Secretary of Defense must prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for military installations within 2 years if deemed necessary. The Secretary of Defense must prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for military installations within 2 years if necessary. If deemed inappropriate under subsection (a)(2)(A), alternative options include preparing a plan agreed upon by the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies, or completing negotiations for a cooperative plan already in effect. The Secretary of Defense must prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for military installations within 2 years. If necessary, negotiations with the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies are required to update existing cooperative plans to comply with the Sikes Act. Public comments must be solicited by the Secretary of Defense. The Secretary of Defense must update existing cooperative plans with State agencies to comply with the Sikes Act. Public comments are solicited on proposed natural resource management plans and changes to cooperative plans. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is amended to include a new subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report must include the number of plans in effect for the year. The Secretary of Defense must review and report annually on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans, including the number of plans in effect and the amount of money spent on conservation activities. The annual report must include the issuance date or latest revision of each plan, the funds spent on conservation activities, and an evaluation of plan compliance with requirements. The annual report under the Legacy Resource Management Program must assess plan compliance with requirements, including ensuring no net loss of lands for military missions. The Secretary of the Interior must submit this report by March 1 each year. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report by March 1, in consultation with State agencies, detailing the funds spent on conservation activities as per integrated natural resource management plans. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with State agencies, must submit an annual report to specific committees on the funds spent on conservation activities outlined in integrated natural resource management plans. The term 'committees' refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws on conservation of natural resources on military installations. SEC. 7 addresses natural resource management services. SEC. 106 allows the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws on conservation of natural resources on military installations within the United States. SEC. 107 addresses natural resource management services. SEC. 107 requires each military department to have trained personnel for natural resource management and law enforcement to comply with the Act by preparing and implementing natural resource management plans. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. This section adds definitions to Title I for clarity and understanding. The term 'military department' refers to the Department of the Army, Navy, and Air Force. A 'military installation' includes land owned by the US and managed by the Secretary of Defense or a military department, including public lands reserved for defense use. The term 'United States' refers to all public lands withdrawn from appropriation under public land laws and reserved for use by the Secretary of Defense or a military department. The term 'State fish and wildlife agency' refers to a state government agency responsible for managing fish and wildlife resources. The term 'United States' includes States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and U.S. territories and possessions. SEC. 9. SHORT TITLE. Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is further amended by inserting after section 108 the following: "SEC. 109. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the 'Sikes Act'." SEC. 10. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. Cost Sharing.--Section 103a(b) is amended by replacing "matching basis" with "cost-sharing basis". Accounting.--Section 103a(c) is amended to exclude section 1535 of that title. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 is repealed. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 (Public Law 99-651; 16 U.S.C. 670a-1) is repealed. SEC. 12. CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended by changing references from "military reservations" to "military installations" in various sections. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended by changing references from "military reservations" to "military installations" in various sections, including section 101(c) and section 102. In various sections of Title I, references to "military reservations" are changed to "military installations" to align with the amendments made by this Act. This includes changes in section 101(c), section 102, section 102, and section 103. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amendments are made to programs on military installations and public lands for the years 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997. HR 3300 RS----2 was passed by the House of Representatives on September 12, 1994.
